statement.tex:
%text Find the relationship between $\alpha$ and $\beta$ so that the function $f(x)$ defined as % \[\qquad f(x) = \begin{cases} \alpha x + 1,\quad x\leq 3 \\ \beta x + 3, \quad x > 3 \end{cases} \] %text
is continuous at $x=3$ %

reason.tex:
See the definition of $f(x)$ again. Only for $x > 3 \implies x\neq 3$ is $f(x) = \beta x + 3$\newline
But for $x \leq 3$ (that is, including $x=3$), $f(x) = \alpha x + 1$. And so, $f(3) = 3\alpha + 1$

options.tex: For $f(x)$ to be continuous at $x=3$ \small\[ \quad \lim_{x\to 3^-} f(x) = \lim_{x\to 3^+} f(x) = f(3) \implies \alpha - \beta = \frac{2}{3}\]\normalsize

reason.tex:
For $f(x)$ to be continuous at $x=3$, \[ \qquad \lim_{x\to 3^-} f(x) = \lim_{x\to 3^+} f(x) = f(3) \]
Now, \[\lim_{x\to 3^-} f(x) = \lim_{x\to 3^-} \left(\alpha x + 1 \right) = 3\alpha + 1 = f(3) \]
And \[\lim_{x\to 3^+} f(x) = \lim_{x\to 3^+} \left(\beta x + 3 \right) = 3\beta + 3\]
Therefore for continuity at $x=3$ \[ 3\alpha + 1 = 3\beta + 3 \implies \alpha - \beta = \frac{2}{3}\]
